review.title: UCP-Networks: A Directed Graphical Representation of Conditional Utilities
review.abstract:
We propose a new directed graphical representation of utility functions, called UCP-networks, that combines aspects of two existing graphical models: generalized additive models and CP-networks. The network decomposes a utility function into a number of additive factors, with the directionality of the arcs reflecting conditional dependence of preference statements - in the underlying (qualitative) preference ordering - under a {em ceteris paribus} (all else being equal) interpretation. This representation is arguably natural in many settings. Furthermore, the strong CP-semantics ensures that computation of optimization and dominance queries is very efficient. We also demonstrate the value of this representation in decision making. Finally, we describe an interactive elicitation procedure that takes advantage of the linear nature of the constraints on "`tradeoff weights" imposed by a UCP-network. This procedure allows the network to be refined until the regret of the decision with minimax regret (with respect to the incompletely specified utility function) falls below a specified threshold (e.g., the cost of further questioning. This approach has also been used for several cases, such as the F-linear-sum function in which we observe the behavior of the network in which it performs the job of evaluating its efficiency or efficiency.

The problem in the first experiment is that the approach for obtaining the right approximation of the curve is quite different. The approach for evaluating the problem for this problem is an iterative approach (a) which is based on the fact that only the one that is able to obtain the right approximation of the curve is at the right time. This is a problem in the first experiment. We have not seen a linear transformation as an efficient method for estimating the error-free equilibrium equation since its implementation was first developed in the 1990s.
